trans-unit.source: Learning PowerShell Workflow
trans-unit.target: Learning PowerShell Workflow

trans-unit.source: Runbooks in Azure Automation are based on Windows PowerShell Workflow.
trans-unit.target: Runbooks in Azure Automation are based on Windows PowerShell Workflow.

trans-unit.source: This article is intended as a quick lesson for authors familiar with PowerShell to understand the specific differences between PowerShell and PowerShell Workflow.
trans-unit.target: This article is intended as a quick lesson for authors familiar with PowerShell to understand the specific differences between PowerShell and PowerShell Workflow.

trans-unit.source: Learning Windows PowerShell Workflow
trans-unit.target: Learning Windows PowerShell Workflow

trans-unit.source: Runbooks in Azure Automation are implemented as Windows PowerShell Workflows.
trans-unit.target: Runbooks in Azure Automation are implemented as Windows PowerShell Workflows.

trans-unit.source: A Windows PowerShell Workflow is similar to a Windows PowerShell script but has some significant differences that can be confusing to a new user.
trans-unit.target: A Windows PowerShell Workflow is similar to a Windows PowerShell script but has some significant differences that can be confusing to a new user.

trans-unit.source: This article is intended for users already familiar with PowerShell and briefly explains concepts that you require if you are converting a PowerShell script to a PowerShell Workflow for use in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: This article is intended for users already familiar with PowerShell and briefly explains concepts that you require if you are converting a PowerShell script to a PowerShell Workflow for use in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: A workflow is a sequence of programmed, connected steps that perform long-running tasks or require the coordination of multiple steps across multiple devices or managed nodes.
trans-unit.target: A workflow is a sequence of programmed, connected steps that perform long-running tasks or require the coordination of multiple steps across multiple devices or managed nodes.

trans-unit.source: The benefits of a workflow over a normal script include the ability to simultaneously perform an action against multiple devices and the ability to automatically recover from failures.
trans-unit.target: The benefits of a workflow over a normal script include the ability to simultaneously perform an action against multiple devices and the ability to automatically recover from failures.

trans-unit.source: A Windows PowerShell Workflow is a Windows PowerShell script that leverages Windows Workflow Foundation.
trans-unit.target: A Windows PowerShell Workflow is a Windows PowerShell script that leverages Windows Workflow Foundation.

trans-unit.source: While the workflow is written with Windows PowerShell syntax and launched by Windows PowerShell, it is processed by Windows Workflow Foundation.
trans-unit.target: While the workflow is written with Windows PowerShell syntax and launched by Windows PowerShell, it is processed by Windows Workflow Foundation.

trans-unit.source: For complete details on the topics in this article, see [Getting Started with Windows PowerShell Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj134242.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For complete details on the topics in this article, see [Getting Started with Windows PowerShell Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj134242.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Types of runbook
trans-unit.target: Types of runbook

trans-unit.source: There are two types of runbook in Azure Automation, *textual* and *graphical*.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of runbook in Azure Automation, *textual* and *graphical*.

trans-unit.source: You define the runbook type when you create the runbook, and you can't convert a runbook to the other type once it's been created.
trans-unit.target: You define the runbook type when you create the runbook, and you can't convert a runbook to the other type once it's been created.

trans-unit.source: Textual runbooks are for users who prefer to work directly with the PowerShell workflow code either using the textual editor in Azure Automation or an offline editor such as PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Textual runbooks are for users who prefer to work directly with the PowerShell workflow code either using the textual editor in Azure Automation or an offline editor such as PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: You should understand the information in this article if you are creating a textual runbook.
trans-unit.target: You should understand the information in this article if you are creating a textual runbook.

trans-unit.source: Graphical runbooks allow you to create a runbook using the same activities and cmdlets but using a graphical interface that hides the complexities of the underlying PowerShell workflow.
trans-unit.target: Graphical runbooks allow you to create a runbook using the same activities and cmdlets but using a graphical interface that hides the complexities of the underlying PowerShell workflow.

trans-unit.source: Concepts in this article such as checkpoints and parallel execution still apply to graphical runbooks, but you won't have to worry about the detailed syntax.
trans-unit.target: Concepts in this article such as checkpoints and parallel execution still apply to graphical runbooks, but you won't have to worry about the detailed syntax.

trans-unit.source: Basic structure of a workflow
trans-unit.target: Basic structure of a workflow

trans-unit.source: The first step to converting a PowerShell script to a PowerShell workflow is enclosing it with the **Workflow** keyword.
trans-unit.target: The first step to converting a PowerShell script to a PowerShell workflow is enclosing it with the **Workflow** keyword.

trans-unit.source: A workflow starts with the **Workflow** keyword followed by the body of the script enclosed in braces.
trans-unit.target: A workflow starts with the **Workflow** keyword followed by the body of the script enclosed in braces.

trans-unit.source: The name of the workflow follows the **Workflow** keyword as shown in the following syntax.
trans-unit.target: The name of the workflow follows the **Workflow** keyword as shown in the following syntax.

trans-unit.source: The name of the workflow must match the name of the Automation runbook.
trans-unit.target: The name of the workflow must match the name of the Automation runbook.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook is being imported, then the filename must match the workflow name and must end in .ps1.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook is being imported, then the filename must match the workflow name and must end in .ps1.

trans-unit.source: To add parameters to the workflow, use the **Param** keyword just as you would to a script.
trans-unit.target: To add parameters to the workflow, use the **Param** keyword just as you would to a script.

trans-unit.source: Code changes
trans-unit.target: Code changes

trans-unit.source: PowerShell workflow code looks almost identical to PowerShell script code except for a few significant changes.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell workflow code looks almost identical to PowerShell script code except for a few significant changes.

trans-unit.source: The following sections describe changes that you will need to make to a PowerShell script for it to run in a workflow.
trans-unit.target: The following sections describe changes that you will need to make to a PowerShell script for it to run in a workflow.

trans-unit.source: Activities
trans-unit.target: Activities

trans-unit.source: An activity is a specific task in a workflow.
trans-unit.target: An activity is a specific task in a workflow.

trans-unit.source: Just as a script is composed of one or more commands, a workflow is composed of one or more activities that are carried out in a sequence.
trans-unit.target: Just as a script is composed of one or more commands, a workflow is composed of one or more activities that are carried out in a sequence.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Workflow automatically converts many of the Windows PowerShell cmdlets to activities when it runs a workflow.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Workflow automatically converts many of the Windows PowerShell cmdlets to activities when it runs a workflow.

trans-unit.source: When you specify one of these cmdlets in your runbook, the corresponding activity is actually run by Windows Workflow Foundation.
trans-unit.target: When you specify one of these cmdlets in your runbook, the corresponding activity is actually run by Windows Workflow Foundation.

trans-unit.source: For those cmdlets without a corresponding activity, Windows PowerShell Workflow automatically runs the cmdlet within an [InlineScript](#inlinescript) activity.
trans-unit.target: For those cmdlets without a corresponding activity, Windows PowerShell Workflow automatically runs the cmdlet within an [InlineScript](#inlinescript) activity.

trans-unit.source: There is a set of cmdlets that are excluded and cannot be used in a workflow unless you explicitly include them in an InlineScript block.
trans-unit.target: There is a set of cmdlets that are excluded and cannot be used in a workflow unless you explicitly include them in an InlineScript block.

trans-unit.source: For further details on these concepts, see [Using Activities in Script Workflows](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574194.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For further details on these concepts, see [Using Activities in Script Workflows](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574194.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Workflow activities share a set of common parameters to configure their operation.
trans-unit.target: Workflow activities share a set of common parameters to configure their operation.

trans-unit.source: For details about the workflow common parameters, see [about_WorkflowCommonParameters](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj129719.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For details about the workflow common parameters, see [about_WorkflowCommonParameters](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj129719.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Positional parameters
trans-unit.target: Positional parameters

trans-unit.source: You can't use positional parameters with activities and cmdlets in a workflow.
trans-unit.target: You can't use positional parameters with activities and cmdlets in a workflow.

trans-unit.source: All this means is that you must use parameter names.
trans-unit.target: All this means is that you must use parameter names.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider the following code that gets all running services.
trans-unit.target: For example, consider the following code that gets all running services.

trans-unit.source: If you try to run this same code in a workflow, you'll get a message like "Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters."
trans-unit.target: If you try to run this same code in a workflow, you'll get a message like "Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters."

trans-unit.source: To correct this, simply provide the parameter name as in the following.
trans-unit.target: To correct this, simply provide the parameter name as in the following.

trans-unit.source: Deserialized objects
trans-unit.target: Deserialized objects

trans-unit.source: Objects in workflows are deserialized.
trans-unit.target: Objects in workflows are deserialized.

trans-unit.source: This means that their properties are still available, but not their methods.
trans-unit.target: This means that their properties are still available, but not their methods.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider the following PowerShell code that stops a service using the Stop method of the Service object.
trans-unit.target: For example, consider the following PowerShell code that stops a service using the Stop method of the Service object.

trans-unit.source: If you try to run this in a workflow, you'll get an error saying "Method invocation is not supported in a Windows PowerShell Workflow".
trans-unit.target: If you try to run this in a workflow, you'll get an error saying "Method invocation is not supported in a Windows PowerShell Workflow".

trans-unit.source: One option is to wrap these two lines of code in an [InlineScript](#InlineScript) block in which case $Service would be a service object within the block.
trans-unit.target: One option is to wrap these two lines of code in an [InlineScript](#InlineScript) block in which case $Service would be a service object within the block.

trans-unit.source: Another option is to use another cmdlet that performs the same functionality as the method, if one is available.
trans-unit.target: Another option is to use another cmdlet that performs the same functionality as the method, if one is available.

trans-unit.source: In the case of our sample, the Stop-Service cmdlet provides the same functionality as the Stop method, and you could use the following for a workflow.
trans-unit.target: In the case of our sample, the Stop-Service cmdlet provides the same functionality as the Stop method, and you could use the following for a workflow.

trans-unit.source: InlineScript
trans-unit.target: InlineScript

trans-unit.source: The **InlineScript** activity is useful when you need to run one or more commands as traditional PowerShell script instead of PowerShell workflow.
trans-unit.target: The **InlineScript** activity is useful when you need to run one or more commands as traditional PowerShell script instead of PowerShell workflow.

trans-unit.source: While commands in a workflow are sent to Windows Workflow Foundation for processing, commands in an InlineScript block are processed by Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: While commands in a workflow are sent to Windows Workflow Foundation for processing, commands in an InlineScript block are processed by Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: InlineScript uses the syntax shown below.
trans-unit.target: InlineScript uses the syntax shown below.

trans-unit.source: You can return output from an InlineScript by assigning the output to a variable.
trans-unit.target: You can return output from an InlineScript by assigning the output to a variable.

trans-unit.source: The following example stops a service and then outputs the service name.
trans-unit.target: The following example stops a service and then outputs the service name.

trans-unit.source: You can pass values into an InlineScript block, but you must use **$Using** scope modifier.
trans-unit.target: You can pass values into an InlineScript block, but you must use **$Using** scope modifier.

trans-unit.source: The following example is identical to the previous example except that the service name is provided by a variable.
trans-unit.target: The following example is identical to the previous example except that the service name is provided by a variable.

trans-unit.source: While InlineScript activities may be critical in certain workflows, they do not support workflow constructs and should only be used when necessary for the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: While InlineScript activities may be critical in certain workflows, they do not support workflow constructs and should only be used when necessary for the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: You cannot use [checkpoints](#Checkpoints) inside of an InlineScript block.
trans-unit.target: You cannot use [checkpoints](#Checkpoints) inside of an InlineScript block.

trans-unit.source: If a failure occurs within the block, it must be resumed from the beginning of the block.
trans-unit.target: If a failure occurs within the block, it must be resumed from the beginning of the block.

trans-unit.source: You cannot use [parallel execution](#parallel-execution) inside of an InlineScriptBlock.
trans-unit.target: You cannot use [parallel execution](#parallel-execution) inside of an InlineScriptBlock.

trans-unit.source: InlineScript affects scalability of the workflow since it holds the Windows PowerShell session for the entire length of the InlineScript block.
trans-unit.target: InlineScript affects scalability of the workflow since it holds the Windows PowerShell session for the entire length of the InlineScript block.

trans-unit.source: For further details on using InlineScript, see [Running Windows PowerShell Commands in a Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574197.aspx) and [about_InlineScript](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj649082.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For further details on using InlineScript, see [Running Windows PowerShell Commands in a Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574197.aspx) and [about_InlineScript](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj649082.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Parallel processing
trans-unit.target: Parallel processing

trans-unit.source: One advantage of Windows PowerShell Workflows is the ability to perform a set of commands in parallel instead of sequentially as with a typical script.
trans-unit.target: One advantage of Windows PowerShell Workflows is the ability to perform a set of commands in parallel instead of sequentially as with a typical script.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **Parallel** keyword to create a script block with multiple commands that will run concurrently.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **Parallel** keyword to create a script block with multiple commands that will run concurrently.

trans-unit.source: This uses the syntax shown below.
trans-unit.target: This uses the syntax shown below.

trans-unit.source: In this case, Activity1 and Activity2 will start at the same time.
trans-unit.target: In this case, Activity1 and Activity2 will start at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Activity3 will start only after both Activity1 and Activity2 have completed.
trans-unit.target: Activity3 will start only after both Activity1 and Activity2 have completed.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider the following PowerShell commands that copy multiple files to a network destination.
trans-unit.target: For example, consider the following PowerShell commands that copy multiple files to a network destination.

trans-unit.source: These commands are run sequentially so that one file must finish copying before the next is started.
trans-unit.target: These commands are run sequentially so that one file must finish copying before the next is started.

trans-unit.source: The following workflow runs these same commands in parallel so that they all start copying at the same time.
trans-unit.target: The following workflow runs these same commands in parallel so that they all start copying at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Only after they are all completely copied is the completion message displayed.
trans-unit.target: Only after they are all completely copied is the completion message displayed.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **ForEach -Parallel** construct to process commands for each item in a collection concurrently.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **ForEach -Parallel** construct to process commands for each item in a collection concurrently.

trans-unit.source: The items in the collection are processed in parallel while the commands in the script block run sequentially.
trans-unit.target: The items in the collection are processed in parallel while the commands in the script block run sequentially.

trans-unit.source: This uses the syntax shown below.
trans-unit.target: This uses the syntax shown below.

trans-unit.source: In this case, Activity1 will start at the same time for all items in the collection.
trans-unit.target: In this case, Activity1 will start at the same time for all items in the collection.

trans-unit.source: For each item, Activity2 will start after Activity1 is complete.
trans-unit.target: For each item, Activity2 will start after Activity1 is complete.

trans-unit.source: Activity3 will start only after both Activity1 and Activity2 have completed for all items.
trans-unit.target: Activity3 will start only after both Activity1 and Activity2 have completed for all items.

trans-unit.source: The following example is similar to the previous example copying files in parallel.
trans-unit.target: The following example is similar to the previous example copying files in parallel.

trans-unit.source: In this case, a message is displayed for each file after it copies.
trans-unit.target: In this case, a message is displayed for each file after it copies.

trans-unit.source: Only after they are all completely copied is the final completion message displayed.
trans-unit.target: Only after they are all completely copied is the final completion message displayed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] We do not recommend running child runbooks in parallel since this has been shown to give unreliable results.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] We do not recommend running child runbooks in parallel since this has been shown to give unreliable results.

trans-unit.source: The output from the child runbook sometimes will not show up, and settings in one child runbook can affect the other parallel child runbooks
trans-unit.target: The output from the child runbook sometimes will not show up, and settings in one child runbook can affect the other parallel child runbooks

trans-unit.source: Checkpoints
trans-unit.target: Checkpoints

trans-unit.source: A *checkpoint* is a snapshot of the current state of the workflow that includes the current value for variables and any output generated to that point.
trans-unit.target: A *checkpoint* is a snapshot of the current state of the workflow that includes the current value for variables and any output generated to that point.

trans-unit.source: If a workflow ends in error or is [suspended](suspending-a-workflow), then the next time it is run it will start from its last checkpoint instead of the start of the worfklow.
trans-unit.target: If a workflow ends in error or is [suspended](suspending-a-workflow), then the next time it is run it will start from its last checkpoint instead of the start of the worfklow.

trans-unit.source: You can set a checkpoint in a workflow with the **Checkpoint-Workflow** activity.
trans-unit.target: You can set a checkpoint in a workflow with the **Checkpoint-Workflow** activity.

trans-unit.source: In the following sample code, an exception occurs after Activity2 causing the workflow to end.
trans-unit.target: In the following sample code, an exception occurs after Activity2 causing the workflow to end.

trans-unit.source: When the workflow is run again, it starts by running Activity2 since this was just after the last checkpoint set.
trans-unit.target: When the workflow is run again, it starts by running Activity2 since this was just after the last checkpoint set.

trans-unit.source: You should set checkpoints in a workflow after activities that may be prone to exception and should not be repeated if the workflow is resumed.
trans-unit.target: You should set checkpoints in a workflow after activities that may be prone to exception and should not be repeated if the workflow is resumed.

trans-unit.source: For example, your workflow may create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: For example, your workflow may create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You could set a checkpoint both before and after the commands to create the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You could set a checkpoint both before and after the commands to create the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If the creation fails, then the commands would be repeated if the workflow is started again.
trans-unit.target: If the creation fails, then the commands would be repeated if the workflow is started again.

trans-unit.source: If the the worfklow fails after the creation succeeds, then the virtual machine will not be created again when the workflow is resumed.
trans-unit.target: If the the worfklow fails after the creation succeeds, then the virtual machine will not be created again when the workflow is resumed.

trans-unit.source: The following example copies multiple files to a network location and sets a checkpoint after each file.
trans-unit.target: The following example copies multiple files to a network location and sets a checkpoint after each file.

trans-unit.source: If the network location is lost, then the workflow will end in error.
trans-unit.target: If the network location is lost, then the workflow will end in error.

trans-unit.source: When it is started again, it will resume at the last checkpoint meaning that only the files that have already been copied will be skipped.
trans-unit.target: When it is started again, it will resume at the last checkpoint meaning that only the files that have already been copied will be skipped.

trans-unit.source: For more information about checkpoints, see [Adding Checkpoints to a Script Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574114.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about checkpoints, see [Adding Checkpoints to a Script Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj574114.aspx).

trans-unit.target: Related articles

trans-unit.target: [Getting Started with Windows PowerShell Workflow](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj134242.aspx)
